column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=custom.Span|label
#T_RL=custom.Relation|label|BT_custom.Span
#Text=Composition of certain _Crude_ and fresh Herbs, such as usually are,
#Text= or may safely be eaten with some _Acetous_ Juice, _Oyl, Salt_, &c. to
#Text= give them a grateful Gust and _Vehicle_; exclusive of the [8][Greek:
#Text= psuchrai trapezai], eaten without their due Correctives, which the
#Text= Learned [9]_Salmasius_, and, indeed generally, the [10]old _Physicians_
#Text= affirm (and that truly) all _Crude_ and raw [Greek: lachana] require
#Text= to render them wholsome; so as probably they were from hence, as
#Text= [11]_Pliny_ thinks, call  '  d _Acetaria_: and not (as _Hermolaus_ and
#Text= some others) _Acceptaria ab Accipiendo_; nor from Accedere, though so
#Text= [12]ready at hand, and easily dress  '  d; requiring neither _Fire, Cost_,
#Text= or _Attendance_, to boil, roast, and prepare them as did Flesh, and
#Text= other Provisions; from which, and other Prerogatives, they were always
#Text= in use, _&c._ And hence indeed the more frugal _Italians_ and _French_,
#Text= to this Day, gather _Ogni Verdura_, any thing almost that  '  s _Green_
#Text= and Tender, to the very Tops of _Nettles_; so as every Hedge affords
#Text= a _Sallet_ (not unagreeable) season  '  d with its proper _Oxybaphon_ of
#Text= _Vinegar, Salt, Oyl_, &c. which doubtless gives it both the Relish
#Text= and Name of _Salad, Emsalada_[13], as with us of _Sallet_; from the
#Text= _Sapidity_, which renders not _Plants_ and _Herbs_ alone, but _Men_
#Text= themselves, and their Conversations, pleasant and agreeable: But of
#Text=_Sparagus_, or sodden in Pottage: There is both a white and red, much
#Text= us  '  d in _Spain_ and _Italy_; but besides its humidity and detersive
#Text= Nature,   '  tis _Insipid_ enough.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 7.
#Text=Borrage, _Borrago_ (_Gaudia semper ago_) hot and kindly moist,
#Text= purifying the Blood, is an exhilarating Cordial, of a pleasant Flavour:
#Text= The tender Leaves, and Flowers especially, may be eaten in Composition;
#Text= but above all, the Sprigs in _Wine_, like those of _Baum_, are of known
#Text= Vertue to revive the _Hypochondriac_, and chear the hard Student.
#Text=See
#Text= _Bugloss_.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 8.
#Text=Brooklime, _Anagallis aquatica_; moderately hot and moist, prevalent
#Text= in the _Scorbute_, and _Stone_.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 9.
#Text=Bugloss, _Buglossum_; in mature much like _Borrage_, yet something
#Text= more astringent.
#Text=The Flowers of both, with the intire Plant, greatly
#Text= restorative, being Conserv  '  d: And for the rest, so much commended by
#Text=20.
#Text=Cucumber, _Cucumis_; tho  '   very cold and moist, the most approved
#Text= _Sallet_ alone, or in Composition, of all the _Vinaigrets_, to sharpen
#Text= the Appetite, and cool the Liver, [16]_&c._ if rightly prepar  '  d; that
#Text= is, by rectifying the vulgar Mistake of altogether extracting the Juice,
#Text= in which it should rather be soak  '  d: Nor ought it to be over _Oyl  '  d_,
#Text= too much abating of its grateful _Acidity_, and _palling_ the Taste from
#Text= a contrariety of Particles: Let them therefore be pared, and cut in
#Text= thin Slices, with a _Clove_ or two of _Onion_ to correct the Crudity,
#Text= macerated in the Juice, often turn  '  d and moderately drain  '  d.
#Text=Others
#Text= prepare them, by shaking the Slices between two Dishes, and dress them
#Text= with very little _Oyl_, well beaten, and mingled with the Juice of
#Text= _Limon, Orange_, or _Vinegar, Salt_ and _Pepper_.
#Text=Some again, (and
#Text= indeed the most approv  '  d) eat them as soon as they are cut, retaining
#Text= their Liquor, which being exhausted (by the former Method) have nothing
#Text= remaining in them to help the Concoction.
#Text=Of old they [17]boil  '  d the
#Text= _Cucumber_, and paring off the Rind, eat them with _Oyl, Vinegar_, and
#Text= _Honey_; _Sugar_ not being so well known.
#Text=Lastly, the _Pulp_ in Broth is
#Text= greatly refreshing, and may be mingl  '  d in most _Sallets_, without the
#Text= least damage, contrary to the common Opinion; it not being long, since
#Text= _Cucumber_, however dress  '  d, was thought fit to be thrown away, being
#Text=accounted little better than Poyson.
#Text=_Tavernier_ tells us, that in
#Text= the _Levant_, if a Child cry for something to Eat, they give it a
#Text= raw _Cucumber_ instead of _Bread_.
#Text=The young ones may be boil  '  d in
#Text= White-Wine.
#Text=The smaller sort (known by the name of _Gerckems_) muriated
#Text= with the Seeds of _Dill_, and the _Mango_ Pickle are for the Winter.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 21.
#Text=Daisy, _Buphthalmum_, Ox-Eye, or _Bellis-major_: The young _Roots_
#Text= are frequently eaten by the _Spaniards_ and _Italians_ all the Spring
#Text= till _June_.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 22.
#Text=Dandelion, _Dens Leonis, Condrilla_: Macerated in several Waters,
#Text= to extract the bitterness; tho  '   somewhat opening, is very wholsome, and
#Text= little inferior to _Succory, Endive_, &c.
#Text=The _French_ Country-People
#Text= eat the Roots; and   '  twas with this homely _Sallet_, the Good-Wife
#Text= _Hecate_ entertain  '  d _Theseus_.
#Text=See _Sowthistle_.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 23.
#Text=Dock, _Oxylapathum_, or sharp-pointed Dock: Emollient, and tho  '
#Text=otherwise not for our _Sallet_, the _Roots_ brewed in _Ale_ or _Beer_,
#Text= are excellent for the _Scorbute_.
#Text=Earth-Nuts, _Bulbo-Castanum_; (found in divers places of _Surry_, near
#Text= _Kingston_, and other parts) the Rind par  '  d off, are eaten crude by
#Text= Rustics, with a little _Pepper_; but are best boil  '  d like other Roots,
#Text= or in Pottage rather, and are sweet and nourishing.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 24.
#Text=Elder, _Sambucus_; The Flowers infus  '  d in _Vinegar_, grateful both
#Text= to the Stomach and Taste; attenuate thick and viscid Humours; and tho  '
#Text= the Leaves are somewhat rank of Smell, and so not commendable in
#Text= _Sallet_; they are otherwise (as indeed is the intire Shrub) of the most
#Text= sovereign Vertue; and the spring Buds and tender Leaves, excellently
#Text= wholsome in Pottage at that Season of the Year.
#Text=See _Flowers_.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 25.
#Text=Endive, _Endivium, Intubum Sativum_; the largest, whitest, and
#Text= tenderest Leaves best boil  '  d, and less crude.
#Text=It is naturally Cold,
#Text=profitable for hot Stomachs; _Incisive_ and opening Obstructions
#Text= of the Liver: The curled is more delicate, being eaten alone, or in
#Text= Composition, with the usual _Intinctus_: It is also excellent being
#Text= boil  '  d; the middle part of the Blanch  '  d-Stalk separated, eats firm, and
#Text= the ampler Leaves by many perferr  '  d before _Lettuce_.
#Text=See _Succory_.
#Text=Eschalot.
#Text=See _Onions_.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 26.
#Text=Fennel, _Foeniculum_: The sweetest of _Bolognia_: Aromatick,
#Text= hot, and dry; expels Wind, sharpens the Sight, and recreates the Brain;
#Text= especially the tender _Umbella_ and Seed-Pods.
#Text=The Stalks are to be
#Text= peel  '  d when young, and then dress  '  d like _Sellery_.
#Text=The tender Tufts and
#Text= Leaves emerging, being minc  '  d, are eaten alone with _Vinegar_, or _Oyl_,
#Text= and _Pepper_, and to correct the colder Materials, enter properly into
#Text= Composition.
#Text=The _Italians_ eat the blanch  '  d Stalk (which they call
#Text= _Cartucci_) all Winter long.
#Text=There is a very small _Green-Worm_, which
#Text= sometimes lodges in the Stemm of this Plant, which is to be taken out,
#Text= as the _Red_ one in that of _Sellery_.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 27.
#Text=Flowers, _Flores_; chiefly of the _Aromatick Esculents_ and
#Text= Plants are preferrable, as generally endow  '  d with the Vertues of their
#Text= _Simples_, in a more intense degree; and may therefore be eaten alone
#Text= in their proper _Vehicles_, or Composition with other _Salleting_,
#Text= sprinkl  '  d among them; But give a more palatable Relish, being Infus  '  d
#Text= in _Vinegar_; Especially those of the _Clove-Gillyflower, Elder, Orange,
#Text= Cowslip, Rosemary, Arch-Angel, Sage, Nasturtium Indicum_, &c.
#Text=Some of
#Text= them are Pickl  '  d, and divers of them make also very pleasant and wholsome
#Text= _Theas_, as do likewise the Wild _Time, Bugloss, Mint_, &c.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 28.
#Text=Garlick, _Allium_; dry towards Excess; and tho  '   both by _Spaniards_
#Text= and _Italians_, and the more Southern People, familiarly eaten, with
#Text= almost every thing, and esteem  '  d of such sigular Vertue to help
#Text= Conception, and thought a Charm against all Infection and Poyson (by
#Text= which it has obtain  '  d the Name of the _Country-man  '  s Theriacle_) we yet
#Text= think it more proper for our Northern Rustics, especially living in
#Text= _Uliginous_ and moist places, or such as use the _Sea_: Whilst we
#Text=and other _Omphacia_, and therefore never to be excluded.
#Text=Vide
#Text= _Wood-Sorrel_.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 62.
#Text=Sow-thistle, _Sonchus_; of the _Intybus_-kind.
#Text=_Galen_ was us  '  d
#Text= to eat it as _Lettuce_; exceedingly welcome to the late _Morocco._
#Text= Ambassador and his Retinue.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 63.
#Text=Sparagus, _Asparagus_ (_ab Asperitate_) temperately hot, and moist;
#Text= _Cordial_, _Diuretic_, easie of Digestion, and next to _Flesh_, nothing
#Text= more nourishing, as _Sim.
#Text=Sethius_, an excellent Physician holds.
#Text=They
#Text= are sometimes, but very seldom, eaten raw with _Oyl_, and _Vinegar_; but
#Text= with more delicacy (the bitterness first exhausted) being so speedily
#Text= boil  '  d, as not to lose the _verdure_ and agreeable tenderness; which is
#Text= done by letting the Water boil, before you put them in.
#Text=I do not esteem
#Text= the _Dutch_ great and larger sort (especially rais  '  d by the rankness of
#Text= the Beds) so sweet and agreeable, as those of a moderate size.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text=64.
#Text=Spinach, _Spinachia_: of old not us  '  d in _Sallets_, and the oftner
#Text= kept out the better; I speak of the _crude_: But being boil  '  d to a
#Text= _Pult_, and without other Water than its own moisture, is a most
#Text= excellent Condiment with _Butter_, _Vinegar_, or _Limon_, for almost
#Text= all sorts of boil  '  d Flesh, and may accompany a Sick Man  '  s Diet
#Text=.
#Text='  Tis
#Text= _Laxative_ and _Emollient_, and therefore profitable for the Aged, and
#Text= (tho  '   by original a _Spaniard_) may be had at almost any Season, and
#Text= in all places.
#Text=Stone-Crop, _Sedum Minus_.
#Text=See _Trick-Madame_.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 65.
#Text=Succory, _Cichorium_, an _Intube_; erratic and wild, with a narrow
#Text= dark Leaf, different from the _Sative_, tho  '   probably by culture only;
#Text= and for being very bitter, a little _edulcorated_ with _Sugar_ and
#Text= _Vinegar_, is by some eaten in the Summer, and more grateful to the
#Text= Stomach than the Palate.
#Text=See _Endive_.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text=66.
#Text=Tansy, _Tanacetum_; hot and cleansing; but in regard of its
#Text= domineering relish, sparingly mixt with our cold _Sallet_, and much
#Text= fitter (tho  '   in very small quantity) for the Pan, being qualified with
#Text= the Juices of other fresh Herbs, _Spinach_, _Green Corn_, _Violet_,
#Text= _Primrose-Leaves_, &c. at entrance of the Spring, and then fried
#Text= brownish, is eaten hot with the Juice of _Orange_ and _Sugar_, as one
#Text= of the most agreeable of all the boil  '  d _Herbaceous_ Dishes.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 67.
#Text=Tarragon, _Draco Herba_, of _Spanish_ Extraction; hot and spicy: The
#Text= Tops and young Shoots, like those of _Rochet_, never to be secluded our
#Text= Composition, especially where there is much _Lettuce_
#Text=.
#Text='  Tis highly
#Text= cordial and friendly to the Head, Heart, Liver, correcting the weakness
#Text= of the Ventricle, _&c._
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 68.
#Text=Thistle, _Carduus Mariæ_; our Lady  '  s milky or dappl  '  d Thistle,
#Text= disarm  '  d of its Prickles, is worth esteem: The young Stalk about _May_,
#Text= being peel  '  d and soak  '  d in Water, to extract the bitterness, boil  '  d or
#Text= raw, is a very wholsome _Sallet_, eaten with _Oyl_, _Salt_, and _Peper_;
#Text=some eat them sodden in proper Broath, or bak  '  d in Pies, like the
#Text= _Artichoak_; but the tender Stalk boil  '  d or fry  '  d, some preferr; both
#Text= Nourishing and Restorative.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 69.
#Text=Trick-Madame, _Sedum minus_, Stone-Crop; is cooling and moist,
#Text= grateful to the Stomach.
#Text=The _Cimata_ and Tops, when young and tender,
#Text= dress  '  d as _Purselane_, is a frequent Ingredient in our cold _Sallet_.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 70.
#Text=Turnep, _Rapum_; moderately hot and moist: _Napus_; the long _Navet_
#Text= is certainly the most delicate of them, and best Nourishing.
#Text=_Pliny_
#Text= speaks of no fewer than six sorts, and of several Colours; some of which
#Text= were suspected to be artificially tinged.
#Text=But with us, the yellow is
#Text= preferr  '  d; by others the red _Bohemian_.
#Text=But of whatever kind, being
#Text= sown upon the _Hot-bed_, and no bigger than seedling _Radish_, they do
#Text= excellently in Composition; as do also the Stalks of the common
#Text= _Turnep_, when first beginning to Bud.
#Text=And here should not be forgotten, that wholsome, as well as agreeable
#Text=sort of _Bread_, we are [42]taught to make; and of which we have eaten
#Text= at the greatest Persons Tables, hardly to be distinguish  '  d from the best
#Text= of _Wheat_.
#Text=Let the _Turneps_ first be peel  '  d, and boil  '  d in Water till soft and
#Text= tender; then strongly pressing out the Juice, mix them together, and
#Text= when dry (beaten or pounded very fine) with their weight of Wheat-Meal,
#Text= season it as you do other _Bread_, and knead it up; then letting the
#Text= Dough remain a little to _ferment_, fashion the Paste into Loaves, and
#Text= bake it like common Bread.
#Text=Some roast _Turneps_ in a Paper under the Embers, and eat them with
#Text= _Sugar_ and _Butter_.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 71.
#Text=Vine, _Vitis_, the _Capreols_, _Tendrels_, and _Claspers_ (like
#Text= those of the _Hop_, &c.) whilst very young, have an agreeable _Acid_,
#Text= which may be eaten alone, or with other _Sallet_.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text=72.
#Text=Viper-grass, _Tragopogon_, _Scorzonera_, _Salsifex_, &c. tho  '
#Text= Medicinal, and excellent against the _Palpitation of the Heart_,
#Text= _Faintings_, _Obstruction of the Bowels_, &c. are besides a very sweet
#Text= and pleasant _Sallet_; being laid to soak out the bitterness, then
#Text= peel  '  d, may be eaten raw, or _Condited_; but best of all stew  '  d with
#Text= _Marrow_, _Spice_, _Wine_, &c. as _Artichoak_, _Skirrets_, &c. sliced or
#Text= whole.
#Text=They likewise may bake, fry, or boil them; a more excellent Root
#Text= there is hardly growing.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 73.
#Text=Wood-Sorrel, _Trifolium acetosum_, or _Alleluja_, of the nature of
#Text= other _Sorrels_.
#Text=To all which might we add sundry more, formerly had in _deliciis_,
#Text= since grown _obsolete_ or quite neglected with us: As among the noblest
#Text= _Bulbs_, that of the _Tulip_; a Root of which has been valued not to
#Text= eat, but for the _Flower_ (and yet eaten by mistake) at more than an
#Text= hundred Pounds.
#Text=The young fresh _Bulbs_ are sweet and high of taste.
#Text=and strong constitutions?
#Text=bessides the hazard of being mistaken in the
#Text= Names of divers _Simples_, not as yet fully agreed upon among the
#Text= Learned in _Botany_.
#Text=There are bessides several remaining, which tho  '   _Abdicated_ here
#Text= with us, find Entertainment still in Foreign Countries: As the large
#Text= _Heliotrope_ and Sun-flower (e  '  re it comes to expand, and shew its
#Text= golden Face) which being dress  '  d as the _Artichoak_, is eaten for a
#Text= dainty.
#Text=This I add as a new Discovery.
#Text=I once made _Macaroons_ with the
#Text= ripe blanch  '  d Seeds, but the _Turpentine_ did so domineer over all, that
#Text= it did not answer expectation.
#Text=The _Radix Personata_ mounting with their
#Text= young Heads, _Lysimachia siliquosa glabra minor_, when fresh and tender,
#Text= begins to come into the _Sallet_-Tribe.
#Text=The pale whiter _Popy_, is eaten
#Text= by the _Genouese_.
#Text=By the _Spaniards_, the tops of _Wormwood_ with _Oyl_
#Text= alone, and without so much as _Bread_; profitable indeed to the Stomach,
#Text= but offensive to the Head; As is also _Coriander_ and _Rue_, which
#Text= _Galen_ was accustom  '  d to eat raw, and by it self, with _Oyl_ and
#Text= _Salt_, as exceedingly grateful, as well as wholsome, and of great
#Text= vertue against Infection.
#Text=_Pliny_, I remember, reports it to be of such
#Text= effect for the Preservation of _Sight_; that the _Painters_ of his Time,
#Text=us  '  d to devour a great quantity of it.
#Text=And it is still by the _Italians_
#Text= frequently mingled among their _Sallets_.
#Text=The _Lapatha Personata_
#Text= (common _Burdock_) comes now and then to the best Tables, about _April_,
#Text= and when young, before the _Burrs_ and _Clots_ appear, being strip  '  d,
#Text= and the bitterness soaked out, treated as the _Chardoon_, is eaten in
#Text= _Poiverade_; Some also boil them.
#Text=More might here be reckon  '  d up, but
#Text= these may suffice; since as we find some are left off, and gone out, so
#Text= others be introduc  '  d and come in their room, and that in much greater
#Text= Plenty and Variety, than was ever known by our Ancestors.
#Text=The _Cucumber_
#Text= it self, now so universally eaten, being accounted little better than
#Text= _Poyson_, even within our Memory, as already noted.
#Text=To conclude, and after all that has been said of Plants and _Salleting_,
#Text= formerly in great esteem, (but since obsolete and quite rejected); What
#Text= if the exalted Juice of the ancient _Silphium_ should come in, and
#Text= challenge the Precedency?
#Text=It is a [43]Plant formerly so highly priz  '  d,
#Text= and rare for the richness of its Taste and other Vertues; that as it was
#Text= dedicated to _Apollo_, and hung up in his Temple at _Delphi_; So we read
#Text= of one single Root brought to the Emperor _Nero_ for an extraordinary
#Text= Present; and the Drug so esteem  '  d, that the _Romans_ had long before
#Text=and _herbaceous_ Animals which feed on Plants, are directed by their
#Text= Smell, and accordingly make election of their Food: But Men (bessides
#Text= the _Smell_ and _Taste_) have, or should have, _Reason_, _Experience_,
#Text= and the Aids of _Natural Philosophy_ to be their Guides in this Matter.
#Text=We have heard _of Plants_, that (like the _Basilisk_) kill and infect by
#Text= [51]looking on them only; and some by the touch.
#Text=The truth is, there  '  s
#Text= need of all the Senses to determine _Analogically_ concerning the
#Text= Vertues and Properties, even of the _Leaves_ alone of many _Edule
#Text= Plants_: The most eminent Principles of near the whole Tribe of _Sallet_
#Text= Vegetables, inclining rather to _Acid_ and _Sowre_ than to any other
#Text= quality, especially, Salt, Sweet, or Luscious.
#Text=There is therefore Skill
#Text= and Judgment requir  '  d, how to suit and mingle our _Sallet_-Ingredients,
#Text= so as may best agree with the Constitution of the (vulgarly reputed)
#Text= _Humors_ of those who either stand in need of, or affect these
#Text= Refreshments, and by so adjusting them, that as nothing should be
#Text= suffer  '  d to domineer, so should none of them lose their genuine Gust,
#Text= Savour, or Vertue.
#Text=To this end,
#Text=
#Text= The Cooler, and moderately refreshing, should be chosen to extinguish
#Text= Thirst, attemper the Blood, repress Vapours, _&c._
#Text=
#Text= The Hot, Dry, Aromatic, Cordial and friendly to the Brain, may be
#Text= qualify  '  d by the Cold and Moist: The Bitter and Stomachical, with the
#Text= _Sub-acid_ and gentler Herbs: The _Mordicant_ and pungent, and such as
#Text= repress or discuss Flatulency (revive the Spirits, and aid Concoction;)
#Text= with such as abate, and take off the keenness, mollify and reconcile the
#Text= more harsh and churlish: The mild and insipid, animated with _piquant_
#Text= and brisk: The Astringent and Binders, with such as are Laxative and
#Text= Deobstruct: The over-sluggish, raw, and unactive, with those that are
#Text= Eupeptic, and promote Concoction: There are _Pectorals_ for the Breast
#Text= and Bowels.
#Text=Those of middle Nature, according as they appear to be more
#Text= or less _Specific_; and as their Characters (tho  '   briefly) are describ  '  d
#Text= in our foregoing _Catalogue_: For notwithstanding it seem in general,
#Text= that raw _Sallets_ and _Herbs_ have experimentally been found to be the
#Text= most soveraign Diet in that _Endemial_ (and indeed with us, _Epidemical_
#Text= and almost universal) Contagion the _Scorbute_, to which we of this
#Text= Nation, and most other _Ilanders_ are obnoxious; yet, since the
#Text= _Nasturtia_ are singly, and alone as it were, the most effectual, and
#Text= powerful Agents in conquering and expugning that cruel Enemy; it were
#Text= enough to give the _Sallet-Dresser_ direction how to choose, mingle, and
#Text=proportion his Ingredients; as well as to shew what Remedies there are
#Text= contain  '  d in our Magazine of _Sallet-Plants_ upon all Occasions, rightly
#Text= marshal  '  d and skilfully apply  '  d.
#Text=So as (with our [52]sweet _Cowley_)
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= _If thro  '   the strong and beauteous Fence_
#Text= _Of Temperance and Innocence,_
#Text= _And wholsome Labours, and a quiet Mind,_
#Text= _Diseases passage find;_
#Text= _They must not think here to assail_
#Text= _A Land unarm  '  d, or without Guard,_
#Text= _They must fight for it, and dispute it hard,_
#Text= _Before they can prevail;_
#Text= _Scarce any Plant is used here,_
#Text= _Which   '  gainst some Aile a Weapon does not bear_.
#Text=We have said how necessary it is, that in the Composure of a _Sallet_,
#Text= every Plant should come in to bear its part, without being over-power  '  d
#Text= by some Herb of a stronger Taste, so as to endanger the native _Sapor_
#Text=and vertue of the rest; but fall into their places, like the _Notes_
#Text= in _Music_, in which there should be nothing harsh or grating: And
#Text= tho  '   admitting some _Discords_ (to distinguish and illustrate the rest)
#Text= striking in the more sprightly, and sometimes gentler Notes, reconcile
#Text= all Dissonancies, and melt them into an agreeable Composition.
#Text=Thus the
#Text= Comical _Master-Cook_, introduc  '  d by _Damoxenus_, when asked [Greek: pôs
#Text= esin autois onmphonia]; _What Harmony there was in Meats_?
#Text=The very
#Text= same (says he) that a _Diatessaron_, _Diapente_, and _Diapason_ have
#Text= one to another in a Consort of Music: And that there was as great care
#Text= requir  '  d, not to mingle [53]_Sapores minime consentientes_, jarring and
#Text= repugnant Tastes; looking upon him as a lamentable Ignorant, who should
#Text= be no better vers  '  d in _Democritus_.
#Text=The whole Scene is very diverting,
#Text= as _Athenæus_ presents it; and to the same sense _Macrobius_, _Saturn.
#Text=lib._ I.
#Text=_cap._ I.
#Text=In short, the main Skill of the Artist lies in this:
#Text=
#Text= _What choice to choose, for delicacy best;_
#Text= _What Order so contriv  '  d, as not to mix_
#Text= _Tastes not well join  '  d, inelegant, but bring_
#Text= _Taste after Taste, upheld by kindliest change_.
#Text=As our [54]_Paradisian Bard_ introduces Eve, dressing of a _Sallet_ for
#Text= her _Angelical_ Guest.
#Text=Thus, by the discreet choice and mixture of the _Oxoleon_ (_Oyl_,
#Text= _Vinegar_, _Salt_, &c.) the Composition is perfect; so as neither the
#Text= _Prodigal_, _Niggard_, nor _Insipid_, should (according to the _Italian_
#Text= Rule) prescribe in my Opinion; since _One_ may be too profuse, the
#Text= _Other_ [55]over-saving, and the _Third_ (like himself) give it no
#Text= Relish at all: It may be too _sharp_, if it exceed a grateful _Acid_;
#Text= too _Insulse_ and flat, if the Profusion be extream.
#Text=From all which
#Text= it appears, that a Wise-Man is the proper Composer of an excellent
#Text= _Sallet_, and how many _Transcendences_ belong to an accomplish  '  d
#Text= _Sallet-Dresser_, so as to emerge an exact _Critic_ indeed, He should
#Text= be skill  '  d in the Degrees, Terms, and various _Species_ of Tastes,
#Text= according to the _Scheme_ set us down in the _Tables_ of the Learned
#Text= [56]Dr.
#Text=_Grew_, to which I refer the Curious
#Text=.
#Text='  Tis moreover to be consider  '  d, that _Edule_ Plants are not in all their
#Text= Tastes and Vertues alike: For as Providence has made us to consist of
#Text=different Parts and Members, both Internal and External; so require they
#Text= different Juices to nourish and supply them: Wherefore the force and
#Text= activity of some Plants lie in the _Root_; and even the _Leaves_ of
#Text= some _Bitter-Roots_ are sweet, and _è contra_.
#Text=Of others, in the _Stem_,
#Text= _Leaves_, _Buds_, _Flowers_, &c.
#Text=Some exert their Vigour without
#Text= _Decoction_; others being a little press  '  d or contus  '  d; others again
#Text= _Raw_, and best in Consort; some alone, and _per se_ without any [Greek:
#Text= skenasia], Preparation, or Mixture at all.
#Text=Care therefore must be taken
#Text= by the _Collector_, that what he gathers answer to these Qualities; and
#Text= that as near as he can, they consist (I speak of the _cruder Salleting_)
#Text= of the _Oluscula_, and _ex foliis pubescentibus_, or (as _Martial_ calls
#Text= them) _Prototomi rudes_, and very tenderest Parts _Gems_, young _Buds_,
#Text= and even first Rudiments of their several Plants; such as we sometimes
#Text= find in the _Craws_ of the _Wood-Culver_, _Stock-Dove_, _Partridge_,
#Text= _Pheasants_, and other Upland Fowl, where we have a natural _Sallet_,
#Text= pick  '  d, and almost dress  '  d to our hands.
#Text=I.
#Text=Preparatory to the Dressing therefore, let your Herby Ingredients
#Text= be exquisitely cull  '  d, and cleans  '  d of all worm-eaten, slimy, canker  '  d,
#Text=dry, spotted, or any ways vitiated Leaves.
#Text=And then that they be rather
#Text= discreetly sprinkl  '  d, than over-much sob  '  d with Spring-Water, especially
#Text= _Lettuce_, which Dr. [57]_Muffet_ thinks impairs their Vertue; but this,
#Text= I suppose he means of the _Cabbage_-kind, whose heads are sufficiently
#Text= protected by the outer Leaves which cover it.
#Text=After washing, let them
#Text= remain a while in the _Cullender_, to drain the superfluous moisture:
#Text= And lastly, swing them altogether gently in a clean course Napkin; and
#Text= so they will be in perfect condition to receive the _Intinctus_
#Text= following.
#Text=II.
#Text=That the _Oyl_, an Ingredient so indispensibly and highly necessary,
#Text= as to have obtain  '  d the name of _Cibarium_ (and with us of _Sallet-Oyl_)
#Text= be very clean, not high-colour  '  d, nor yellow; but with an Eye rather of
#Text= a pallid _Olive_ green, without Smell, or the least touch of _rancid_,
#Text= or indeed of any other sensible Taste or Scent at all; but smooth,
#Text= light, and pleasant upon the Tongue; such as the genuine _Omphacine_,
#Text= and native _Luca Olives_ afford, fit to allay the tartness of _Vinegar_,
#Text= and other _Acids_, yet gently to warm and humectate where it passes.
#Text=Some who have an aversion to _Oyl_, substitute fresh _Butter_ in its
#Text=Medica_) which may be justly call  '  d _Infallible Specifics_, and upon
#Text= whose Performance we may as safely depend, as we may on such as
#Text= familiarly we use for a Crude _Herb-Sallet;_ discreetly chosen, mingl  '  d,
#Text= and dress  '  d accordingly: Not but that many of them may be improv  '  d, and
#Text= render  '  d better in Broths, and Decoctions, than in _Oyl_, _Vinegar_,
#Text= and other Liquids and Ingredients: But as this holds not in all, nay,
#Text= perhaps in few comparatively, (provided, as I said, the Choice, Mixture,
#Text= Constitution, and _Season_ rightly be understood) we stand up in Defence
#Text= and Vindication of our _Sallet_, against all Attacks and Opposers
#Text= whoever.
#Text=We have mentioned _Season_ and with the great _Hippocrates_, pronounce
#Text= them more proper for the Summer, than the Winter; and when those Parts
#Text= of Plants us  '  d in _Sallet_ are yet tender, delicate, and impregnated
#Text= with the Vertue of the Spring, to cool, refresh, and allay the Heat and
#Text= Drought of the Hot and _Bilious_, Young and over-_Sanguine_, Cold,
#Text= _Pituit_, and Melancholy; in a word, for Persons of all Ages, Humours,
#Text= and Constitutions whatsoever.
#Text=To this of the _Annual Seasons_, we add that of _Culture_ also, as of
#Text=very great Importance: And this is often discover  '  d in the taste and
#Text= consequently in the Goodness of such Plants and _Salleting_, as are
#Text= Rais  '  d and brought us fresh out of the Country, compar  '  d with those
#Text= which the Avarice of the _Gardiner_, or Luxury rather of the Age, tempts
#Text= them to force and _Resuscitate_ of the most desirable and delicious
#Text= Plants.
#Text=It is certain, says a [71]Learned Person, that about populous Cities,
#Text= where Grounds are over-forc  '  d for Fruit and early _Salleting_, nothing
#Text= is more unwholsom: Men in the Country look so much more healthy and
#Text= fresh; and commonly are longer liv  '  d than those who dwell in the Middle
#Text= and Skirts of vast and crowded Cities, inviron  '  d with rotten Dung,
#Text= loathsome and common Lay Stalls; whose noisome Steams, wafted by the
#Text= Wind, poison and infect the ambient Air and vital Spirits, with those
#Text= pernicious Exhalations, and Materials of which they make the _Hot Beds_
#Text= for the raising those _Præcoces_ indeed, and forward Plants and Roots
#Text= for the wanton Palate; but which being corrupt in the Original, cannot
#Text= but produce malignant and ill Effects to those who feed upon them.
#Text=And
#Text= the same was well observ  '  d by the _Editor_ of our famous _Roger Bacon  '  s_
#Text= Treatise concerning the _Cure of Old Age_, and _Preservation of Youth_:
#Text=There being nothing so proper for _Sallet Herbs_ and other _Edule
#Text= Plants_, as the Genial and Natural Mould, impregnate, and enrich  '  d
#Text= with well-digested Compost (when requisite) without any Mixture of
#Text= Garbage, odious Carrion, and other filthy Ordure, not half consum  '  d and
#Text= ventilated and indeed reduc  '  d to the next Disposition of Earth it self,
#Text= as it should be; and that in Sweet, [72]Rising, Aery and moderately
#Text= Perflatile Grounds; where not only _Plants_ but _Men_ do last, and live
#Text= much longer.
#Text=Nor doubt I, but that every body would prefer Corn, and
#Text= other Grain rais  '  d from _Marle_, _Chalk_, _Lime_, and other sweet Soil
#Text= and Amendments, before that which is produc  '  d from the _Dunghil_ only.
#Text=Beside, Experience shews, that the Rankness of _Dung_ is frequently the
#Text= Cause of Blasts and Smuttiness; as if the _Lord_ of the _Universe_,
#Text= by an Act of visible Providence would check us, to take heed of all
#Text= unnatural Sordidness and Mixtures.
#Text=We sensibly find this Difference
#Text= in Cattle and their Pasture; but most powerfully in _Fowl_, from such
#Text= as are nourish  '  d with Corn, sweet and dry Food: And as of Vegetable
#Text= _Meats_, so of _Drinks_,   '  tis observ  '  d, that the same Vine, according
#Text= to the Soil, produces a _Wine_ twice as heady as in the same, and a
#Text= less forc  '  d Ground; and the like I believe of all other Fruit, not to
#Text= determine any thing of the _Peach_ said to be Poison in _Persia_;
#Text=because   '  tis a _Vulgar Error_.
#Text=Now, because among other things, nothing more betrays its unclean and
#Text= spurious Birth than what is so impatiently longed after as _Early
#Text= Asparagus_, &c. [73]Dr.
#Text=_Lister_, (according to his communicative and
#Text= obliging Nature) has taught us how to raise such as our _Gardiners_
#Text= cover with nasty Litter, during the Winter; by rather laying of
#Text= Clean and Sweet _Wheat-Straw_ upon the Beds, _super-seminating_ and
#Text= over-strowing them thick with the Powder of bruised _Oyster-Shells_,
#Text= &c. to produce that most tender and delicious _Sallet_.
#Text=In the mean
#Text= while, if nothing will satisfie save what is rais  '  d _Ex tempore_, and
#Text= by Miracles of Art so long before the time; let them study (like the
#Text= _Adepti_) as did a very ingenious Gentleman whom I knew; That having
#Text= some Friends of his accidentally come to Dine with him, and wanting an
#Text= early Sallet, Before they sate down to Table, sowed _Lettuce_ and some
#Text= other Seeds in a certain Composition of Mould he had prepared; which
#Text= within the space of two Hours, being risen near two Inches high,
#Text= presented them with a delicate and tender _Sallet_; and this, without
#Text= making use of any nauseous or fulsome Mixture; but of Ingredients not
#Text= altogether so cheap perhaps.
#Text=_Honoratus Faber_ (no mean _Philosopher_)
#Text=Vitellius _his Table, to which every Day_
#Text= _All Courtiers did a constant Tribute pay,_
#Text= _Could nothing more delicious afford_
#Text= _Than Nature  '  s Liberality._
#Text= _Help  '  d with a little Art and Industry,_
#Text= _Allows the meanest Gard  '  ners Board,_
#Text= _The Wanton Taste no Fish or Fowl can chuse,_
#Text= _For which the Grape or Melon she would lose._
#Text= _Tho  '   all th  '   Inhabitants of Sea and Air._
#Text= _Be lifted in the Glutton  '  s Bill of Fare;_
#Text= _Yet  still the_ Sallet, _and the_ Fruit _we see_
#Text= _Plac  '  d the third Story high in all her Luxury_.
#Text=So the Sweet [110]_Poet_, whom I can never part with for his Love to
#Text= this delicious Toil, and the Honour he has done me.
#Text=Verily, the infinite Plenty and Abundance, with which the benign and
#Text= bountiful Author of Nature has stor  '  d the whole Terrestrial World, more
#Text= with _Plants_ and _Vegetables_ than with any other Provision whatsoever;
#Text=and the Variety not only equal, but by far exceeding the Pleasure
#Text= and Delight of Taste (above all the Art of the _Kitchen_, than ever
#Text= [111]_Apicius_ knew) seems loudly to call, and kindly invite all her
#Text= living Inhabitants (none excepted) who are of gentle Nature, and most
#Text= useful, to the same _Hospitable_ and Common-Board, which first she
#Text= furnish  '  d with _Plants_ and _Fruit_, as to their natural and genuine
#Text= Pasture; nay, and of the most wild, and savage too _ab origine_: As in
#Text= _Paradise_, where, as the _Evangelical_ [112]Prophet adumbrating the
#Text= future Glory of the _Catholick Church_, (of which that happy _Garden_
#Text= was the _Antitype_) the _Wolf and the Lamb, the angry and furious Lion,
#Text= should eat Grass and Herbs together with the Ox_.
#Text=But after all, _latet
#Text= anguis in herba_, there  '  s a _Snake_ in the Grass; Luxury, and Excess in
#Text= our most innocent Fruitions.
#Text=There was a time indeed when the Garden
#Text= furnish  '  d Entertainments for the most Renown  '  d Heroes, virtuous and
#Text= excellent Persons; till the Blood-thirsty and Ambitious, over-running
#Text= the Nations, and by Murders and Rapine rifl  '  d the World, to transplant
#Text= its Luxury to its new Mistriss, _Rome_.
#Text=Those whom heretofore [113]two
#Text= Acres of Land would have satisfied, and plentifully maintain  '  d; had
#Text= afterwards their very Kitchens almost as large as their first
#Text= Territories: Nor was that enough: Entire [114]_Forests_ and _Parks_,
#Text=That nobler Part, dull  '  d and depress  '  d we find.
#Text=Drowsie and unapt for Business, and other nobler Parts of Life.
#Text=Time was before Men in those golden Days: Their Spirits were brisk and
#Text= lively.
#Text=----_Ubi dicto citius curata sopori_
#Text= _Membra dedit, Vegetus præscripta ad munera surgit_.
#Text=With shorter, but much sweeter Sleep content,
#Text= Vigorous and fresh, about their Business went.
#Text=And Men had their Wits about them; their Appetites were natural, their
#Text= Sleep _molli sub arbore_, sound, sweet, and kindly: That excellent
#Text= Emperour _Tacitus_ being us  '  d to say of _Lettuce_, that he did _somnum
#Text= se mercari_ when he eat of them, and call  '  d it a sumptuous Feast, with
#Text= a _Sallet_ and a single _Pullet_, which was usually all the Flesh-Meat
#Text= that sober Prince eat of; whilst _Maximinus_ (a profess  '  d Enemy to
#Text=Gilly-flowers
#Text=.
#Text=/
#Text=
#Text= Herbs.
#Text=_See_ Pudding _and_ Tart.
#Text=Limon.
#Text=_See_ Pickle.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 3.
#Text=Mushroom.
#Text=_Chuse the small, firm and white Buttons_, growing _upon
#Text= sweet Pasture_ _Grounds, neither under, or about any Trees: strip off
#Text= the upper Skin, and pare away all the black spungy Bottom part; then
#Text= slice them in quarters, and cast them in Water a while to cleanse: Then
#Text= Boil them in fresh Water, and a little sweet Butter; (some boil them a
#Text= quarter of an hour first) and then taking them out, dry them in a Cloth,
#Text= pressing out the Water, and whilst hot, add the Butter; and then boiling
#Text= a full Hour (to exhaust the Malignity) shift them in another clean
#Text= Water, with Butter, as before till they become sufficiently tender.
#Text=Then
#Text= being taken out, pour upon them as much strong Mutton (or other) Broth
#Text= as will cover them, with six Spoonfuls of White-Wine, twelve Cloves, as
#Text= many Pepper-Corns, four small young Onions, half an Handful of Persly
#Text= bound up with two or three Spriggs of Thyme, an_ Anchovy, _Oysters raw,
#Text=or pickl  '  d; a little Salt, sweet Butter; and so let them stew_.
#Text=_See_
#Text= Acetar. p. 26.
#Text=Another.
#Text=_Prepared, and cleans  '  d as above, and cast into Fountain-Water, to
#Text= preserve them from growing black; Boil them in fresh Water and Salt; and
#Text= whilst on the Fire, cast in the_ Mushrooms, _letting them boil till they
#Text= become tender: Then stew them leisurely between two Dishes (the Water
#Text= being drained from them) in a third Part of White-Wine_ _and Butter, a
#Text= small Bundle of sweet Herbs at discretion.
#Text=To these add Broth as before,
#Text= with Cloves, Mace, Nutmeg_, Anchovies (_one is sufficient_) _Oysters_,
#Text= &c.
#Text=_a small Onion, with the green Stem chopt small; and lastly, some
#Text= Mutton-Gravy, rubbing the Dish gently with a Clove of Garlick, or some_
#Text= Rocombo _Seeds in its stead.
#Text=Some beat the Yolk of a fresh Egg with
#Text= Vinegar, and Butter, and a little Pepper_.
#Text=_In_ France _some (more compendiously being peel  '  d and prepared) cast
#Text=them into a Pipkin, where, with the Sweet Herbs, Spices, and an Onion
#Text= they stew them in their own Juice, without any other Water or Liquor at
#Text= all; and then taking out the Herbs and Onion, thicken it with a little
#Text= Butter, and so eat them_.
#Text=_In_ Poiverade.
#Text=_The large Mushrooms well cleansed_, &c.
#Text=_being cut into quarters and
#Text= strewed with Pepper and Salt, are broil  '  d on the Grid-iron, and eaten
#Text= with fresh Butter_.
#Text=_In_ Powder.
#Text=_Being fresh gathered, cleans  '  d_, &c.
#Text=_and cut in Pieces, stew them
#Text= in Water and Salt; and being taken forth, dry them with a Cloth: Then
#Text= putting them into an Earth-Glazed Pot, set them into the Oven after the
